an9.37:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ āyasmā ānando kosambiyaṃ viharati ghositārāme.
an9.37:1.1.eng: At one time Venerable Ānanda was staying near Kosambī, in Ghosita’s Monastery.

an9.37:1.2.pli: Tatra kho āyasmā ānando bhikkhū āmantesi:

an9.37:1.4.pli: “Āvuso”ti kho te bhikkhū āyasmato ānandassa paccassosuṃ.

an9.37:2.2.pli: Yāvañcidaṃ tena bhagavatā jānatā passatā arahatā sammāsambuddhena sambādhe okāsādhigamo anubuddho sattānaṃ visuddhiyā sokaparidevānaṃ samatikkamāya dukkhadomanassānaṃ atthaṅgamāya ñāyassa adhigamāya nibbānassa sacchikiriyāya.
an9.37:2.2.eng: How this Blessed One who knows and sees, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha, has found an opening amid confinement. It’s in order to purify sentient beings, to get past sorrow and crying, to make an end of pain and sadness, to discover the system, and to realize extinguishment.

an9.37:2.3.pli: Tadeva nāma cakkhuṃ bhavissati te rūpā tañcāyatanaṃ no paṭisaṃvedissati.
an9.37:2.3.eng: The eye itself is actually present, and so are those sights. Yet one will not experience that sense-field.

an9.37:2.4.pli: Tadeva nāma sotaṃ bhavissati te saddā tañcāyatanaṃ no paṭisaṃvedissati.
an9.37:2.4.eng: The ear itself is actually present, and so are those sounds. Yet one will not experience that sense-field.

an9.37:2.5.pli: Tadeva nāma ghānaṃ bhavissati te gandhā tañcāyatanaṃ no paṭisaṃvedissati.
an9.37:2.5.eng: The nose itself is actually present, and so are those smells. Yet one will not experience that sense-field.

an9.37:2.6.pli: Sāva nāma jivhā bhavissati te rasā tañcāyatanaṃ no paṭisaṃvedissati.
an9.37:2.6.eng: The tongue itself is actually present, and so are those tastes. Yet one will not experience that sense-field.

an9.37:2.7.pli: Sova nāma kāyo bhavissati te phoṭṭhabbā tañcāyatanaṃ no paṭisaṃvedissatī”ti.
an9.37:2.7.eng: The body itself is actually present, and so are those touches. Yet one will not experience that sense-field.”

an9.37:3.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, āyasmā udāyī āyasmantaṃ ānandaṃ etadavoca:
an9.37:3.1.eng: When he said this, Venerable Udāyī said to Venerable Ānanda:

an9.37:3.2.pli: “saññīmeva nu kho, āvuso ānanda, tadāyatanaṃ no paṭisaṃvedeti udāhu asaññī”ti?
an9.37:3.2.eng: “Reverend Ānanda, is one who doesn’t experience that sense-field actually percipient or not?”

an9.37:3.3.pli: “Saññīmeva kho, āvuso, tadāyatanaṃ no paṭisaṃvedeti, no asaññī”ti.
an9.37:3.3.eng: “Reverend, one who doesn’t experience that sense-field is actually percipient, not non-percipient.”

an9.37:4.1.eng: “But what does one who doesn’t experience that sense-field perceive?”

an9.37:4.2.pli: “Idhāvuso, bhikkhu, sabbaso rūpasaññānaṃ samatikkamā paṭighasaññānaṃ atthaṅgamā nānattasaññānaṃ amanasikārā ‘ananto ākāso’ti ākāsānañcāyatanaṃ upasampajja viharati.
an9.37:4.2.eng: “It’s when a mendicant, going totally beyond perceptions of form, with the disappearance of perceptions of impingement, not focusing on perceptions of diversity, aware that ‘space is infinite’, enters and remains in the dimension of infinite space.

an9.37:4.3.pli: Evaṃsaññīpi kho, āvuso, tadāyatanaṃ no paṭisaṃvedeti.
an9.37:4.3.eng: One who doesn’t experience that sense-field perceives in this way.

an9.37:5.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, āvuso, bhikkhu sabbaso ākāsānañcāyatanaṃ samatikkamma ‘anantaṃ viññāṇan’ti viññāṇañcāyatanaṃ upasampajja viharati.
an9.37:5.1.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant, going totally beyond the dimension of infinite space, aware that ‘consciousness is infinite’, enters and remains in the dimension of infinite consciousness.

an9.37:5.2.pli: Evaṃsaññīpi kho, āvuso, tadāyatanaṃ no paṭisaṃvedeti.
an9.37:5.2.eng: One who doesn’t experience that sense-field perceives in this way.

an9.37:6.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, āvuso, bhikkhu sabbaso viññāṇañcāyatanaṃ samatikkamma ‘natthi kiñcī’ti ākiñcaññāyatanaṃ upasampajja viharati.
an9.37:6.1.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant, going totally beyond the dimension of infinite consciousness, aware that ‘there is nothing at all’, enters and remains in the dimension of nothingness.

an9.37:6.2.pli: Evaṃsaññīpi kho, āvuso, tadāyatanaṃ no paṭisaṃvedetīti.
an9.37:6.2.eng: One who doesn’t experience that sense-field perceives in this way.

an9.37:7.1.pli: Ekamidāhaṃ, āvuso, samayaṃ sākete viharāmi añjanavane migadāye.
an9.37:7.1.eng: Reverend, this one time I was staying near Sāketa in the deer park in Añjana Wood.

an9.37:7.2.pli: Atha kho, āvuso, jaṭilavāsikā bhikkhunī yenāhaṃ tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā maṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ aṭṭhāsi. Ekamantaṃ ṭhitā kho, āvuso, jaṭilavāsikā bhikkhunī maṃ etadavoca:
an9.37:7.2.eng: Then the nun Jaṭilagāhikā came up to me, bowed, stood to one side, and said to me:

an9.37:7.3.pli: ‘yāyaṃ, bhante ānanda, samādhi na cābhinato na cāpanato na ca sasaṅkhāraniggayhavāritagato,
an9.37:7.3.eng: ‘Honorable Ānanda, regarding the immersion that does not lean forward or pull back, and is not held in place by forceful suppression.

an9.37:7.4.pli: vimuttattā ṭhito, ṭhitattā santusito, santusitattā no paritassati.
an9.37:7.4.eng: Being free, it’s stable. Being stable, it’s content. Being content, one is not anxious.

an9.37:7.5.pli: Ayaṃ, bhante ānanda, samādhi kiṃphalo vutto bhagavatā’ti?
an9.37:7.5.eng: What did the Buddha say was the fruit of this immersion?’

an9.37:8.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, sohaṃ, āvuso, jaṭilavāsikaṃ bhikkhuniṃ etadavocaṃ:
an9.37:8.1.eng: When she said this, I said to her:

an9.37:8.2.pli: ‘yāyaṃ, bhagini, samādhi na cābhinato na cāpanato na ca sasaṅkhāraniggayhavāritagato,
an9.37:8.2.eng: ‘Sister, regarding the immersion that does not lean forward or pull back, and is not held in place by forceful suppression.

an9.37:8.3.pli: vimuttattā ṭhito, ṭhitattā santusito, santusitattā no paritassati.
an9.37:8.3.eng: Being free, it’s stable. Being stable, it’s content. Being content, one is not anxious.

an9.37:8.4.pli: Ayaṃ, bhagini, samādhi aññāphalo vutto bhagavatā’ti.
an9.37:8.4.eng: The Buddha said that the fruit of this immersion is enlightenment.’

an9.37:8.5.pli: Evaṃsaññīpi kho, āvuso, tadāyatanaṃ no paṭisaṃvedetī”ti.
an9.37:8.5.eng: One who doesn’t experience that sense-field perceives in this way, too.”

an9.38:1.1.pli: Atha kho dve lokāyatikā brāhmaṇā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavatā saddhiṃ sammodiṃsu.
an9.38:1.1.eng: Then two brahmin cosmologists went up to the Buddha, and exchanged greetings with him.

an9.38:1.2.pli: Sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu. Ekamantaṃ nisinnā kho te brāhmaṇā bhagavantaṃ etadavocuṃ:
an9.38:1.2.eng: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, they sat down to one side and said to the Buddha:

an9.38:2.1.pli: “Pūraṇo, bho gotama, kassapo sabbaññū sabbadassāvī aparisesaṃ ñāṇadassanaṃ paṭijānāti:
an9.38:2.1.eng: “Worthy Gotama, Pūraṇa Kassapa claims to be all-knowing and all-seeing, to know and see everything without exception, thus:

an9.38:2.2.pli: ‘carato ca me tiṭṭhato ca suttassa ca jāgarassa ca satataṃ samitaṃ ñāṇadassanaṃ paccupaṭṭhitan’ti.
an9.38:2.2.eng: ‘Knowledge and vision are constantly and continually present to me, while walking, standing, sleeping, and waking.’

an9.38:2.4.pli: ‘ahaṃ anantena ñāṇena anantaṃ lokaṃ jānaṃ passaṃ viharāmī’ti.
an9.38:2.4.eng: ‘With infinite knowledge I know and see that the cosmos is infinite.’

an9.38:2.5.pli: Ayampi, bho gotama, nigaṇṭho nāṭaputto sabbaññū sabbadassāvī aparisesaṃ ñāṇadassanaṃ paṭijānāti:
an9.38:2.5.eng: And the Jain ascetic of the Ñātika clan also claims to be all-knowing and all-seeing, to know and see everything without exception, thus:

an9.38:2.6.pli: ‘carato ca me tiṭṭhato ca suttassa ca jāgarassa ca satataṃ samitaṃ ñāṇadassanaṃ paccupaṭṭhitan’ti.
an9.38:2.6.eng: ‘Knowledge and vision are constantly and continually present to me, while walking, standing, sleeping, and waking.’

an9.38:2.8.pli: ‘ahaṃ anantena ñāṇena anantaṃ lokaṃ jānaṃ passaṃ viharāmī’ti.
an9.38:2.8.eng: ‘With infinite knowledge I know and see that the cosmos is finite.’

an9.38:2.9.pli: Imesaṃ, bho gotama, ubhinnaṃ ñāṇavādānaṃ ubhinnaṃ aññamaññaṃ vipaccanīkavādānaṃ ko saccaṃ āha ko musā”ti?
an9.38:2.9.eng: These two claim to speak from knowledge, but they directly contradict each other. Which one of them speaks the truth, and which falsehood?”

an9.38:3.3.pli: ‘imesaṃ ubhinnaṃ ñāṇavādānaṃ ubhinnaṃ aññamaññaṃ vipaccanīkavādānaṃ ko saccaṃ āha ko musā’ti.

an9.38:3.4.eng: I will teach you the Dhamma.

an9.38:3.5.pli: taṃ suṇātha, sādhukaṃ manasi karotha, bhāsissāmī”ti.
an9.38:3.5.eng: Listen and apply your mind well, I will speak.”

an9.38:3.6.pli: “Evaṃ, bho”ti kho te brāhmaṇā bhagavato paccassosuṃ.

an9.38:4.1.pli: “Seyyathāpi, brāhmaṇā, cattāro purisā catuddisā ṭhitā paramena javena ca samannāgatā paramena ca padavītihārena.
an9.38:4.1.eng: “Suppose there were four men standing in the four quarters. Each of them was extremely fast, with an extremely mighty stride.

an9.38:4.2.pli: Te evarūpena javena samannāgatā assu, seyyathāpi nāma daḷhadhammā dhanuggaho sikkhito katahattho katūpāsano lahukena asanena appakasirena tiriyaṃ tālacchāyaṃ atipāteyya;
an9.38:4.2.eng: They’re as fast as a light arrow easily shot across the shadow of a palm tree by a well-trained expert archer with a strong bow.

an9.38:4.3.pli: evarūpena ca padavītihārena, seyyathāpi nāma puratthimā samuddā pacchimo samuddo
an9.38:4.3.eng: Their stride was such that it spanned from the eastern ocean to the western ocean.

an9.38:4.4.pli: atha puratthimāya disāya ṭhito puriso evaṃ vadeyya:
an9.38:4.4.eng: Then the man standing in the east would say:

an9.38:4.5.eng: ‘I will reach the end of the world by traveling.’

an9.38:4.6.pli: So aññatreva asitapītakhāyitasāyitā aññatra uccārapassāvakammā aññatra niddākilamathapaṭivinodanā vassasatāyuko vassasatajīvī vassasataṃ gantvā appatvāva lokassa antaṃ antarā kālaṃ kareyya.
an9.38:4.6.eng: Though he’d travel for his whole lifespan of a hundred years—pausing only to eat and drink, go to the toilet, and sleep to dispel weariness—he’d die along the way, never reaching the end of the world.

an9.38:4.7.eng: Then the man standing in the west …

an9.38:4.8.eng: Then the man standing in the north …

an9.38:4.9.pli: atha dakkhiṇāya disāya ṭhito puriso evaṃ vadeyya:
an9.38:4.9.eng: Then the man standing in the south would say:

an9.38:4.10.eng: ‘I will reach the end of the world by traveling.’

an9.38:4.11.pli: So aññatreva asitapītakhāyitasāyitā aññatra uccārapassāvakammā aññatra niddākilamathapaṭivinodanā vassasatāyuko vassasatajīvī vassasataṃ gantvā appatvāva lokassa antaṃ antarā kālaṃ kareyya.
an9.38:4.11.eng: Though he’d travel for his whole lifespan of a hundred years—pausing only to eat and drink, go to the toilet, and sleep to dispel weariness—he’d die along the way, never reaching the end of the world.

an9.38:4.13.pli: Nāhaṃ, brāhmaṇā, evarūpāya sandhāvanikāya lokassa antaṃ ñāteyyaṃ daṭṭheyyaṃ patteyyanti vadāmi.
an9.38:4.13.eng: I say it’s not possible to know or see or reach the end of the world by running like this.

an9.38:4.14.pli: Na cāhaṃ, brāhmaṇā, appatvāva lokassa antaṃ dukkhassa antakiriyaṃ vadāmi.
an9.38:4.14.eng: But I also say there’s no making an end of suffering without reaching the end of the world.

an9.38:5.1.pli: Pañcime, brāhmaṇā, kāmaguṇā ariyassa vinaye lokoti vuccati.
an9.38:5.1.eng: These five kinds of sensual stimulation are called the world in the training of the Noble One.

an9.38:5.3.pli: Cakkhuviññeyyā rūpā iṭṭhā kantā manāpā piyarūpā kāmūpasaṃhitā rajanīyā;
an9.38:5.3.eng: Sights known by the eye, which are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.

an9.38:5.7.pli: kāyaviññeyyā phoṭṭhabbā iṭṭhā kantā manāpā piyarūpā kāmūpasaṃhitā rajanīyā;
an9.38:5.7.eng: Touches known by the body, which are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.

an9.38:5.8.pli: ime kho, brāhmaṇā, pañca kāmaguṇā ariyassa vinaye lokoti vuccati.
an9.38:5.8.eng: These five kinds of sensual stimulation are called the world in the training of the Noble One.

an9.38:6.1.pli: Idha, brāhmaṇā, bhikkhu vivicceva kāmehi vivicca akusalehi dhammehi savitakkaṃ savicāraṃ vivekajaṃ pītisukhaṃ paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati.
an9.38:6.1.eng: Take a mendicant who, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, enters and remains in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected.

an9.38:6.2.pli: Ayaṃ vuccati, brāhmaṇā, ‘bhikkhu lokassa antamāgamma, lokassa ante viharati’.
an9.38:6.2.eng: This is called a mendicant who, having gone to the end of the world, meditates at the end of the world.

an9.38:6.4.eng: ‘They’re included in the world, and haven’t yet left the world.’

an9.38:6.6.eng: ‘They’re included in the world, and haven’t yet left the world.’

an9.38:7.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, brāhmaṇā, bhikkhu vitakkavicārānaṃ vūpasamā …pe… dutiyaṃ jhānaṃ …
an9.38:7.1.eng: Furthermore, take a mendicant who, as the placing of the mind and keeping it connected are stilled, enters and remains in the second absorption …

an9.38:7.4.pli: Ayaṃ vuccati, brāhmaṇā, ‘bhikkhu lokassa antamāgamma lokassa ante viharati’.
an9.38:7.4.eng: This is called a mendicant who, having gone to the end of the world, meditates at the end of the world.

an9.38:7.6.eng: ‘They’re included in the world, and haven’t yet left the world.’

an9.38:7.8.eng: ‘They’re included in the world, and haven’t yet left the world.’

an9.38:8.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, brāhmaṇā, bhikkhu sabbaso rūpasaññānaṃ samatikkamā paṭighasaññānaṃ atthaṅgamā nānattasaññānaṃ amanasikārā ‘ananto ākāso’ti ākāsānañcāyatanaṃ upasampajja viharati.
an9.38:8.1.eng: Furthermore, take a mendicant who, going totally beyond perceptions of form, with the disappearance of perceptions of impingement, not focusing on perceptions of diversity, aware that ‘space is infinite’, enters and remains in the dimension of infinite space.

an9.38:8.2.pli: Ayaṃ vuccati, brāhmaṇā, ‘bhikkhu lokassa antamāgamma lokassa ante viharati’.
an9.38:8.2.eng: This is called a mendicant who, having gone to the end of the world, meditates at the end of the world.

an9.38:8.4.eng: ‘They’re included in the world, and haven’t yet left the world.’

an9.38:8.6.eng: ‘They’re included in the world, and haven’t yet left the world.’

an9.38:9.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, brāhmaṇā, bhikkhu sabbaso ākāsānañcāyatanaṃ samatikkamma ‘anantaṃ viññāṇan’ti viññāṇañcāyatanaṃ upasampajja viharati …pe…
an9.38:9.1.eng: Furthermore, take a mendicant who enters and remains in the dimension of infinite consciousness. …

an9.38:9.2.pli: sabbaso viññāṇañcāyatanaṃ samatikkamma ‘natthi kiñcī’ti ākiñcaññāyatanaṃ upasampajja viharati …pe…

an9.38:9.3.pli: sabbaso ākiñcaññāyatanaṃ samatikkamma nevasaññānāsaññāyatanaṃ upasampajja viharati.
an9.38:9.3.eng: the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception.

an9.38:9.4.pli: Ayaṃ vuccati, brāhmaṇā, ‘bhikkhu lokassa antamāgamma lokassa ante viharati’.
an9.38:9.4.eng: This is called a mendicant who, having gone to the end of the world, meditates at the end of the world.

an9.38:9.6.eng: ‘They’re included in the world, and haven’t yet left the world.’

an9.38:9.8.eng: ‘They’re included in the world, and haven’t yet left the world.’

an9.38:10.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, brāhmaṇā, bhikkhu sabbaso nevasaññānāsaññāyatanaṃ samatikkamma saññāvedayitanirodhaṃ upasampajja viharati, paññāya cassa disvā āsavā parikkhīṇā honti.
an9.38:10.1.eng: Furthermore, take a mendicant who, going totally beyond the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception, enters and remains in the cessation of perception and feeling. And, having seen with wisdom, their defilements come to an end.

an9.38:10.2.pli: Ayaṃ vuccati, brāhmaṇā, ‘bhikkhu lokassa antamāgamma lokassa ante viharati tiṇṇo loke visattikan’”ti.
an9.38:10.2.eng: This is called a mendicant who, having gone to the end of the world, meditates at the end of the world. And they’ve crossed over clinging to the world.”

an9.39:0.3.eng: The War Between the Gods and the Titans

an9.39:1.1.eng: “Once upon a time, mendicants, a battle was fought between the gods and the titans.

an9.39:1.2.pli: Tasmiṃ kho pana, bhikkhave, saṅgāme asurā jiniṃsu, devā parājayiṃsu.
an9.39:1.2.eng: In that battle the titans won and the gods lost.

an9.39:1.3.pli: Parājitā ca, bhikkhave, devā apayiṃsuyeva uttarenābhimukhā, abhiyiṃsu asurā.
an9.39:1.3.eng: Defeated, the gods fled north with the titans in pursuit.

an9.39:1.6.eng: Why don’t we engage them in battle a second time?’

an9.39:1.7.pli: Dutiyampi kho, bhikkhave, devā asurehi saṅgāmesuṃ.
an9.39:1.7.eng: And so a second battle was fought between the gods and the titans.

an9.39:1.8.pli: Dutiyampi kho, bhikkhave, asurāva jiniṃsu, devā parājayiṃsu.
an9.39:1.8.eng: And for a second time the titans won and the gods lost.

an9.39:1.9.pli: Parājitā ca, bhikkhave, devā apayiṃsuyeva uttarenābhimukhā, abhiyiṃsu asurā.
an9.39:1.9.eng: Defeated, the gods fled north with the titans in pursuit.

an9.39:2.3.eng: Why don’t we engage them in battle a third time?’

an9.39:2.4.pli: Tatiyampi kho, bhikkhave, devā asurehi saṅgāmesuṃ.
an9.39:2.4.eng: And so a third battle was fought between the gods and the titans.

an9.39:2.5.pli: Tatiyampi kho, bhikkhave, asurāva jiniṃsu, devā parājayiṃsu.
an9.39:2.5.eng: And for a third time the titans won and the gods lost.

an9.39:2.6.pli: Parājitā ca, bhikkhave, devā bhītā devapuraṃyeva pavisiṃsu.
an9.39:2.6.eng: Defeated and terrified, the gods fled right into the castle of the gods.

an9.39:2.7.eng: When they had entered their castle, they thought,

an9.39:2.8.pli: ‘bhīruttānagatena kho dāni mayaṃ etarahi attanā viharāma akaraṇīyā asurehī’ti.
an9.39:2.8.eng: ‘Now we’re in a secure location and the titans can’t do anything to us.’

an9.39:2.10.pli: ‘bhīruttānagatena kho dāni devā etarahi attanā viharanti akaraṇīyā amhehī’ti.
an9.39:2.10.eng: ‘Now the gods are in a secure location and we can’t do anything to them.’

an9.39:3.1.eng: Once upon a time, a battle was fought between the gods and the titans.

an9.39:3.2.pli: Tasmiṃ kho pana, bhikkhave, saṅgāme devā jiniṃsu, asurā parājayiṃsu.
an9.39:3.2.eng: In that battle the gods won and the titans lost.

an9.39:3.3.pli: Parājitā ca, bhikkhave, asurā apayiṃsuyeva dakkhiṇenābhimukhā, abhiyiṃsu devā.
an9.39:3.3.eng: Defeated, the titans fled south with the gods in pursuit.

an9.39:3.6.eng: Why don’t we engage them in battle a second time?’

an9.39:3.7.pli: Dutiyampi kho, bhikkhave, asurā devehi saṅgāmesuṃ.
an9.39:3.7.eng: And so a second battle was fought between the gods and the titans.

an9.39:3.8.pli: Dutiyampi kho, bhikkhave, devā jiniṃsu, asurā parājayiṃsu.
an9.39:3.8.eng: And for a second time the gods won and the titans lost.

an9.39:3.9.pli: Parājitā ca, bhikkhave, asurā apayiṃsuyeva dakkhiṇenābhimukhā, abhiyiṃsu devā.
an9.39:3.9.eng: Defeated, the titans fled south with the gods in pursuit.

an9.39:4.3.eng: Why don’t we engage them in battle a third time?’

an9.39:4.4.pli: Tatiyampi kho, bhikkhave, asurā devehi saṅgāmesuṃ.
an9.39:4.4.eng: And so a third battle was fought between the gods and the titans.

an9.39:4.5.pli: Tatiyampi kho, bhikkhave, devā jiniṃsu, asurā parājayiṃsu.
an9.39:4.5.eng: And for a third time the gods won and the titans lost.

an9.39:4.6.pli: Parājitā ca, bhikkhave, asurā bhītā asurapuraṃyeva pavisiṃsu.
an9.39:4.6.eng: Defeated and terrified, the titans fled right into the citadel of the titans.

an9.39:4.7.eng: When they had entered their citadel, they thought,

an9.39:4.8.pli: ‘bhīruttānagatena kho dāni mayaṃ etarahi attanā viharāma akaraṇīyā devehī’ti.
an9.39:4.8.eng: ‘Now we’re in a secure location and the gods can’t do anything to us.’

an9.39:4.10.pli: ‘bhīruttānagatena kho dāni asurā etarahi attanā viharanti akaraṇīyā amhehī’ti.
an9.39:4.10.eng: ‘Now the titans are in a secure location and we can’t do anything to them.’

an9.39:5.1.pli: Evamevaṃ kho, bhikkhave, yasmiṃ samaye bhikkhu vivicceva kāmehi vivicca akusalehi dhammehi savitakkaṃ savicāraṃ vivekajaṃ pītisukhaṃ paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati,
an9.39:5.1.eng: In the same way, there’s a time when a mendicant, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, enters and remains in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected.

an9.39:5.2.pli: tasmiṃ, bhikkhave, samaye bhikkhussa evaṃ hoti:
an9.39:5.2.eng: At that time the mendicant thinks,

an9.39:5.3.pli: ‘bhīruttānagatena kho dānāhaṃ etarahi attanā viharāmi akaraṇīyo mārassā’ti.
an9.39:5.3.eng: ‘Now I’m in a secure location and Māra can’t do anything to me.’

an9.39:5.4.eng: And Māra the Wicked also thinks,

an9.39:5.5.pli: ‘bhīruttānagatena kho dāni bhikkhu etarahi attanā viharati akaraṇīyo mayhan’ti.
an9.39:5.5.eng: ‘Now the mendicant is in a secure location and we can’t do anything to them.’

an9.39:6.1.pli: Yasmiṃ, bhikkhave, samaye bhikkhu vitakkavicārānaṃ vūpasamā …pe… dutiyaṃ jhānaṃ …
an9.39:6.1.eng: There’s a time when, as the placing of the mind and keeping it connected are stilled, a mendicant enters and remains in the second absorption …

an9.39:6.4.pli: tasmiṃ, bhikkhave, samaye bhikkhussa evaṃ hoti:
an9.39:6.4.eng: At that time the mendicant thinks,

an9.39:6.5.pli: ‘bhīruttānagatena kho dānāhaṃ etarahi attanā viharāmi akaraṇīyo mārassā’ti.
an9.39:6.5.eng: ‘Now I’m in a secure location and Māra can’t do anything to me.’

an9.39:6.6.eng: And Māra the Wicked also thinks,

an9.39:6.7.pli: ‘bhīruttānagatena kho dāni bhikkhu etarahi attanā viharati, akaraṇīyo mayhan’ti.
an9.39:6.7.eng: ‘Now the mendicant is in a secure location and we can’t do anything to them.’

an9.39:7.1.pli: Yasmiṃ, bhikkhave, samaye bhikkhu sabbaso rūpasaññānaṃ samatikkamā paṭighasaññānaṃ atthaṅgamā nānattasaññānaṃ amanasikārā ‘ananto ākāso’ti ākāsānañcāyatanaṃ upasampajja viharati.
an9.39:7.1.eng: There’s a time when a mendicant, going totally beyond perceptions of form, with the disappearance of perceptions of impingement, not focusing on perceptions of diversity, aware that ‘space is infinite’, enters and remains in the dimension of infinite space.

an9.39:7.2.pli: Ayaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, ‘bhikkhu antamakāsi māraṃ, apadaṃ vadhitvā māracakkhuṃ adassanaṃ gato pāpimato tiṇṇo loke visattikan’ti.
an9.39:7.2.eng: This is called a mendicant who has blinded Māra, put out his eyes without a trace, and gone where the Wicked One cannot see.

an9.39:8.1.pli: Yasmiṃ, bhikkhave, samaye bhikkhu sabbaso ākāsānañcāyatanaṃ samatikkamma ‘anantaṃ viññāṇan’ti viññāṇañcāyatanaṃ upasampajja viharati …
an9.39:8.1.eng: There’s a time when a mendicant, going totally beyond the dimension of infinite space, aware that ‘consciousness is infinite’, enters and remains in the dimension of infinite consciousness. …

an9.39:8.2.pli: sabbaso viññāṇañcāyatanaṃ samatikkamma ‘natthi kiñcī’ti ākiñcaññāyatanaṃ upasampajja viharati …
an9.39:8.2.eng: Going totally beyond the dimension of infinite consciousness, aware that ‘there is nothing at all’, they enter and remain in the dimension of nothingness. …

an9.39:8.3.pli: sabbaso ākiñcaññāyatanaṃ samatikkamma nevasaññānāsaññāyatanaṃ upasampajja viharati …
an9.39:8.3.eng: Going totally beyond the dimension of nothingness, they enter and remain in the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception. …

an9.39:8.4.pli: sabbaso nevasaññānāsaññāyatanaṃ samatikkamma saññāvedayitanirodhaṃ upasampajja viharati, paññāya cassa disvā āsavā parikkhīṇā honti.
an9.39:8.4.eng: Going totally beyond the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception, they enter and remain in the cessation of perception and feeling. And, having seen with wisdom, their defilements come to an end.

an9.39:8.5.pli: Ayaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, ‘bhikkhu antamakāsi māraṃ, apadaṃ vadhitvā māracakkhuṃ adassanaṃ gato pāpimato tiṇṇo loke visattikan’”ti.
an9.39:8.5.eng: This is called a mendicant who has blinded Māra, put out his eyes without a trace, and gone where the Wicked One cannot see. And they’ve crossed over clinging to the world.”
